The Italian Campaign Series: MedWar, is the fourth & final game in the series. This game adds a strategic map of the Mediterranean Sea around Italy and adds full Air and Naval operations to the game system. The game cannot be played by itself... ownership of Sicily, Salerno, and Anzio, are required. This game was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #160.

Numerous scenarios and campaign games are provided. Each one uses counters and maps from all of the preceding games in the series. Victory is determined by the scenario being played.

Eleven pages of additional errata and clarifications for rules, maps, and counters are also included in the S&T magazine for all of the games in the series.

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 to 2 days
Hex: 5 miles
Unit: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
One countersheet (240 1/2" counters)
One 20 page rule booklet
6002.name: The Italian Campaign: Med War

boardgamehonor: 1989 Charles S. Roberts Best Post-World War II Board Game Nominee
6003.description:
Donau Front: Ardennes of the ‘90s: The Bavarian Option in the Next War, is the second game in the renewed Central Front series of games which include: North German Plain, BAOR, Fifth Corps, and Hof Gap. Maps from all of the renewed series games may be linked and rules exist for a full Campaign game. Donau Front was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #131. The games are designed to depict hypothetical Warsaw Pact versus NATO conflict during the first five days of a future war.

Victory is measured by the PACT player's attainment of certain objectives, and the NATO player's denial of these. Objectives range from advancing to a specific hex row, to occupying Munich. Four different objective types exist, so it is possible for both players to "win".

Rules are provided to link this game with Hof Gap.

Game Scale:
Turn: 6 hour daylight & 12 hour nighttime turns
Hex: 4 km
Unit: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
One countersheet (200 1/2" counters)
One 16 page rules booklet (Central Front Standard Rules & Donau Front Exclusive Rules)
6003.name: Donau Front

boardgamehonor: 1988 Charles S. Roberts Best Pre-World War II Board Game Nominee
6004.description:
The Indian Mutiny is a simulation of the Sepoy Rebellion in 1857.

The game includes a 22"X34" map, 8 page rules and scenarios booklet, and 200 counters.

Extensive conditions for either the British or Indian players determines which side wins (depending on the scenario being played).
6004.name: The Indian Mutiny

boardgamehonor: 1987 Charles S. Roberts Best Post-World War II Board Game Nominee
6005.description:
Korea is a regimental/divisional level game of the first year of the UN Operations in 1950-51. One player commands the units of the Korean People's Army and the allied Chinese People's Liberation Army; the other player controls the Republic of Korea armed forces and the allied U.N. coalition Army containing U.S., British, Philippine, Turkish, Canadian, and Thai forces. This game was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #111.

Included are a 22"X34" map sheet, 200 counters (units and markers) and a 12 page rulebook.

Multiple historical and 'what if?' scenarios are provided, each with its own victory conditions, usually based on points gained by the KPA/PLA player for controlling certain geographical areas.
6005.name: Korea: The Mobile War

6006.description:
Iron Cross is a man-to-man wargame covering infantry battles, on a tactical level, between German and Soviet forces in Russia during 1941-42. The game was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #132.

The game has been called "the poor man's Squad Leader", but does a great job simulating small unit tactics in the six provided scenarios.

Game Scale:
Turn: 2 minutes
Map: 10 meters
Unit: Individual man, weapon, vehicle

Game Contents:
One 22 x 34" map (designed to be hand cut to give three 12 x 18" maps)
One countersheet (200 1/2" counters)
One 20 page rulebook
6006.name: Iron Cross

6007.description:
Fortress Stalingrad: Soviet Winter Counter Offensive 1942-1943, is a strategic/operational level simulation of the Soviet Winter Counter Offensive in 1942-43. Many have called this to be the single most important Campaign in all of World War II. The game was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #124.

The Soviet player gains victory points based on objectives and German unit losses. If he gains more than 110 points in the 12 game turns, he wins. If the German player holds the Soviets to less than 100 points, he wins.

The game is declared a draw if the point total is between 100 and 110.

Game Scale:
Turn: approximately 10 days
Hex: 15 miles / 25 km
Unit: Company to Army

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 30" mapsheet
One countersheet (200 1/2" counters)
One 20 page rules booklet
6007.name: Fortress Stalingrad

6008.description:
Ruweisat Ridge: The First Battle of El Alamein, was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #105. The game covers the desert battles around El Alamein from July 1 through July 18, 1942. The British Commonwealth 8th Army must hold the line against the battered Panzerarmee Afrika, since Alexandria and the virtually undefended Nile Delta lie less than 100 miles to the east.

The map depicts the battlefield of El Alamein, from the Mediterranean Sea in the north, to the virtually impassable Qattara Depression in the south.

The game system tries out some unusual mechanics to simulate the fast-paced flow of desert warfare. Combat units are rated for firepower and assault strength, while AFVs have an armor rating, and artillery has an anti-tank rating. HQs are used for activation of units in their formation. Rules of interest are Opportunity Fire, Overruns, Reaction Movement and Withdrawal Fire, Airstrikes and Fortifications.

Victory is determined by points gained through objective hexes, enemy units eliminated, and for occupying portions of the 'coast road'... the player with the most points wins. The difference in points between the Commonwealth and Axis player determines the level of victory.

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 day
Hex: 1.5 miles
Unit: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 16" X 21" mapsheet
One countersheet (100 1/2" counters)
One 12 page rules booklet
6008.name: Ruweisat Ridge: The First Battle of El Alamein

6009.description:
Soldiers of the Queen is actually two separate Colonial battle games that use the same game system: Isandhlwana, 1879 and Omdurman, 1898. The game was originally published in Strategy & Tactics magazine (#95).

The game includes an 18"X22" backprinted mapsheet (one side for each battle), a 16 page rulebook, 200 counters, and player aid charts and tables.

In Isandhlwana, the Zulu player wins if he eliminates all British units before he himself loses 14, otherwise the British player wins; the game has no set time limit... it is played until one player or the other has achieved their victory conditions.

In Omdurman, points are gained for each player according to a victory points chart... if the British do not win an 'Automatic Victory' by turn 21, the side with the higher point total wins.
6009.name: Soldiers of the Queen: Battles at Isandhlwana and Omdurman

boardgamehonor: 2003 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "Published games" Nominee
2003 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "Published games" Winner
2003 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Nominee
2004 Vuoden Peli Children's Game of the Year Winner
6010.description:
How awful, four children have entered the Ghost Ride to be scared. But the cars suddenly stop, and all of the turning ghosts stand still. The gears are broken, and it is up to the children to fix the gears to make the ghosts turn.

A clever children's game where players must use logic (logi) to move ghosts (geists)through use of gears placed over pegs.
boardgameversion: Finnish edition with Vuoden Lastenpeli award
6010.name: Phantom Rallye

6011.description:
This is a children's race game based on the transportation system of the Monorail and Casey Jr. train at Disneyland. Players race not only each other, but the train, Casey Jr. (a non-player character). Roll the dice, using the white die for your own movement on the monorail track and the colored die to move Casey on the train track.

Pure luck, no decisions at all, and Casey can win the game. But it is a cute depiction of Disneyland transportation, and amazing that it still applies perfectly 40-some years later!
6011.name: Disneyland Monorail Game

6012.name: Mary Poppins Carousel Game
6012.description:
This is a children's race game that matches portions of the Mary Poppins movie.

It is a simple roll and move game that is pure luck with no player choices to make. There is a spinner built into the board that is used only at the end when a player at the final space spins to match their color/player token. If the spinner does not land on their color, they wait and try again next turn.

This is NOT the Mary Poppins game that has a 3-D carousel, although it was produced around the same time.

6013.name: Cranium Cosmo
6013.description:
Push back from your desk, grab the next card from Cosmo, and you're on your way to five minutes of high-fiving fun. Cranium Cosmo is bursting with brilliant ways to have a few moments of unconventional, uncontrollable fun on your own or with friends at the office.
Each time you pull a card from Cosmo, you’ll find yourself creating, noodling, puzzling, playing, and sharing laughs with coworkers as you enjoy Cosmo’s 15 different outrageous activities. Ever tried bowling with dry-erase markers as pins? How fast can you type your name with your nose? Can you use Cranium Cubes™ to build a crossword puzzle containing a pet’s name? With Cranium Cosmo, you’ll never believe how creative and fun office breaks can be!

6014.name: The Whale Game
6014.description:
Play as migrating Humpback whales attempting to avoid Hazards and accumulate 'survival points' in order to win the game. Choose safer waters or attempt to navigate shorter but riskier waters, grown the size of your Humpback family, and play Bonus cards at the right time to ensure your survival or save them to earn additional points at game end.

But this game is more than about winning where you also learn about these majestic creatures. All Hazard and Bonus cards have carefully researched 'Whale Facts' that help you learn about other life forms and be sensitive to environments beyond what you readily know. There are also opportunities to help other players' whales, such as those that have been beached, which give you additional bonus cards and further the survival of the species as a whole. Whales further ahead in the game can choose to 'wait' and encourage the survival of more whales before returning to their home waters (which immediately ends the game)

The environmental group Green Peace has promoted this game and part of the profits go to helping save whales.

GAMEPLAY
The main objective is Whale Survival through the accumulation of points. You roll the die then navigate your whale pod (family) along the paths starting at the Home Waters heading south to warmer waters for the winter, into family waters to find a mate and give birth to young, then head back north again to the Home Waters attempting to end on the same specific location you started from.

Along the way you encounter Hazards (cards you draw) which hinder your progress and also obtain 'Bonus' cards which may help you move along faster or avoid Hazards later in the game.

The larger your family (up to 4 members) plus bonuses from unused cards and finishing first help determine the winner.

6015.description:
The object of Double Cross is to be the first player to position five marbles in a row, either vertically, horizobtally, or diagonally.

Place the larger cross in the center of the table. Each arm should point to one of the players. Each players will play his marbles on the arm closest to him. Put the smaller cross on top of the larger cross.

Each player takes 15 marbles and one red funnel marker. He place the red funnel marker in any of the 5 holes in the arm of the upper cross closest to him.

The active player is called the Double Crosser. The Double Crosser tries to move the upper cross so that he can make a good move for himself while all of the other players have to make bad moves.

Each turn consist of 5 steps for the active player.
1) Each players, except the Double Crosser, must move his red funnel marker to another hole on his arm of the upper cross.
2) The Double Crosser roll the die. a white face means the lost of his turn.
3) On a red or black result of the die, he tells the other players the number of the square to which he will move the upper cross center, accordingly to the color rolled by the die.
4) The Double Crosser moves the upper cross so that the center hole is right on top of that number.
5) Each player than drops one marble throught his red funnel marker. a player can drop a marble only into an empty marble hole.
6015.name: Double Cross

6016.name: Capital Power
6016.description:
A game set in the world of finance in which the winner is not the best prepared economically, but the most able in procuring non-existent fund or in founding ghost companies.

Contents:

170 bank notes, divided into black and white dollars.
70 registers to record the life of the various companies.
30 stock shares for the control of the central bank.
1 large table in rigid, plasticized cardboard. Printed in 5 colors, giving the courses of action to be followed.
25 company pieces in metal.
1 rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
1 plastic storage tray and one die.

boardgamehonor: 1989 Charles S. Roberts Best World War II Board Game Nominee
6017.description:
Blitzkrieg `41 is a two-player strategic level wargame of the German invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941.

The game includes a 20 page rulebook, 200 counters, and a 22" x 34" mapsheet which contains a map plus charts and tables for both players.

Victory conditions are quite extensive (over a page of rules) and, because of the great number of draws that the game will produce (the historical result), the designer recommends playing multiple games for total points.
6017.name: Blitzkrieg '41

6018.name: Gipso
6018.description:
According to the throw of the die, players move their markers along the squares, until they assemble the naif puzzle corresponding to the chosen season. The game is provided with 4 puzzles which are already a game in themselves.

Contents

Playing board in rigid, thick cardboard, plasticized, with matte finish and cut in 5 pieces.
Pieces in coloured plastic.
4 puzzles of 24 pieces each in rigid, thick cardboard, plasticized, with matte finish representing the four seasons.
Small plastic bag containing the puzzles.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.

6019.name: Tablin
6019.description:
The first (and only) expansion for VII Legio, with new rules, equipments and aliens.

Expands:

VII Legio

6020.description:
This game is a simulation of the Battle for Moscow, 1812, first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #136; errata appears in S&T #138.

Included in the game are rules, a 22"X34" mapsheet, and 200 counters.

Two scenarios are provided: a historical scenario (where units are placed as they were actually deployed) and a hypothetical scenario (where players are free to deploy where they wish).

Victory is solely based on Russian strength losses, the French player must eliminate at least 90 strength points to win. (approximately 40% of the Russian army).
6020.name: Borodino: Doomed Victory

6021.description:
First published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #110, Hastings, 1066 is a tactical simulation of the confrontation between William the Bastard, Duke of Normandy, and King Harold Godwineson of Wessex... a battle that forever changed the face of the world, as the victor became King.

The game includes a 12 page rulebook, 200 counters and a 22"X34" mapsheet, which includes player displays, charts, and tables.

The Norman's objective was to reach and take London. Harold's army blocked the only road. If the Norman player controls all of the road hexes on Senlac Hill, they win a Strategic victory. The Normans also win if they can eliminate all of the Saxon housecarle units. If neither of these victory conditions occur by the end of the second assult phase, the Saxon player wins.
6021.name: Hastings, 1066

6022.description:
This game is an operational simulation of the American Revolutionary War from late 1775 (the siege of Boston and the two Canadian expeditions) through the end of 1781. The British player must try to stop the revolt by trying to control half a continent.

Included are a 16 page rulebook, 22"X34" map, 200 counters, and various player charts and tables.

The British player wins in one of two ways. If the year is 1775 or 1776, the British player requires control of a limited number of objectives (Canada, Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Charleston, and one area of operations). If the game continues to 1781, the British player must control New England, the Middle Colonies, the South, and either Canada or the Western Territories. If the British do not attain these objectives, the American player wins.
6022.name: 13: The Colonies in Revolt

6023.description:
The Thunder at Luetzen game is an army level simulation of the opening of Napoleon's 1813 campaign in Germany. The game was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #99.

THe game consists of a 16 page rulebook, one 22"X34" mapsheet, 200 counters and various player aids.

Leadership and morale play an important part of the game. Combat is by strength differential. If neither the French nor Allied army is demoralized by the end of 32 game turns, the French player wins if he controls Leipzig Bridge, otherwise the Allied player wins.
6023.name: Thunder at Luetzen

6024.description:
This game is a simulation of the Polish resistance in Warsaw during 1944. The game was originally published in Strategy & Tactics magazine (#107).

The game includes a 16 page rulebook (covering all aspects of guerrila warfare and resistance combat), 200 counters (representing the units and weapons involved in the conflict) and a 22"X34" map of the City of Warsaw.

Two scenarios are provided: Warsaw Rises! (August 1944 - 4 turns) and The German Juggernaut (September, 1944 - 5 turns). Victory is based on capturing or assaulting various buildings in the city, eliminating enemy units, and (for the German player) maintaining a supply line through Warsaw. Points may also be spent during the game for additional reinforcements. The player with the most victory points at the end of the scenario, wins.
6024.name: Warsaw Rising: Revolt of the Polish Underground, 1944

6025.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #2: Battle of the Bulge
boardgamefamily: World War 2: Battle of the Bulge
6025.description:
2nd of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around tank combat in World War 2.

6026.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #3: The Battle of Sekigahara
6026.description:
3rd of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in Japan in 1600.

6027.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #4: The Battle of Britain
6027.description:
4th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in World War 2, with Britain fighting the Germans in the skies.

6028.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #5: The Battle of Kawanakajima
6028.description:
5th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around a battle in medieval Japan that took place in 1561.

6029.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #6: D-Day
6029.description:
6th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers D-Day, of course.

6030.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #7: The Siege of Osaka in the Summer
6030.description:
7th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around the Siege of Osaka in 1615 (in the summer!). The Summer Battle was actually a field battle-the siege of the Castle had taken place over the Winter of 1614-15. The official English title on the box is "The Sierge of Osaka in the Summer", but "Sierge" is a typo/mistranslation on their part.

6031.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #8: Battle of the Midway
6031.description:
8th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around airplane combat in the Pacific Ocean between America and Japan during World War 2.

6032.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #9: Battle of Nagashino
6032.description:
9th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in 1575 Japan. One interesting aspect of the battle simulated was that there was a traitor who switched sides early in the fight. In the game, if his side takes 3 of more casaulties in turn 1, he switches sides immediately. If not, he remains loyal throughout the game.

6033.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #10: Battle of Pearl Harbor
6033.description:
10th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around the bombing of Pearl Harbor in World War 2.

6034.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #11: Battle of Dannoura
6034.description:
11th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers a battle in Japan, in the year 1185.

6035.name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #12: Afrika Korps
6035.description:
12th and final of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around infantry and tank combat in the desert during World War 2.

boardgamehonor: 1992 Charles S. Roberts Best Post World War II Board Game Nominee
1992 Charles S. Roberts Best Post World War II Board Game Winner
6036.description:
Tet `68 is a simulation of the 1968 Tet Offensive in Vietnam. The objective of the game is to show what happened during the campaign, how the U.S. and its allies, despite winning a military victory, were defeated psychologically and politically.

Included are a large 22" x 34" map of Vietnam, 200 counters, and extensive 16 page rulebook, including rules for intelligence, logistics, and weather.

Victory is awarded based on points, which are earned in different ways for the Communist and U.S. players. Communist points are scored for political successes; U.S. points are primarily scored for military objectives. At the end of 7 game turns, the player with the highest victory point total is the winner.
6036.name: Tet '68

boardgamehonor: 1993 Charles S. Roberts Best Pre-World War II Board Game Nominee
1993 Charles S. Roberts Best Wargaming Graphics Nominee
6037.description:
A two-player wargame that covers the epic three month siege of Tenochtitlan, the climactic battle for control of Mexico, fought in 1521.
14 pages of rules, 144 5/8" counters, and a 22" x 34" map are included.

This game is the only one that I am aware of that includes rules for Human Sacrifice...

If Cortes is killed or captured, the Aztec player wins immediately. Otherwise, the Spanish player must keep his "Loss Points" to a minimum... as long as the Spanish player does not gain 17 or more points, they win.
6037.name: Cortes: Conquest of the Aztec Empire

6038.description:
Shogun Triumphant is a two-player historical simulation of the most famous land battle in Japanese history: The Battle of Sekigahara.

Included are a 14 page booklet of rules, charts and tables, a 22" x 34" map of the battlefield, and 158 counters.

Units are broken into factions and clans... one player commands the Eastern Army, the other player commands the West. Extensive rules for Melee Combat, Clan Effectivenes, and Defections are provided.

Victory is determined by counting loss of "Stalwartness Points". The first player to drop 160 points due to losses and defections, loses the game. If the game manages to last eight turns, without either player losing, the Western player is assumed to win.
6038.name: Shogun Triumphant

6039.description:
Antietam: Burnished Rows of Steel is a game of the bloodiest single-day battle in the American Civil War.

Game turns are sequential, with each player moving, firing artillery, and then having two rounds of combat, each in turn. Also provided are rules for solitaire play.
Victory is determined by victory points earned by the Union player for capturing and maintaining control of geographical objectives and Confederate unit losses. If the Confederate player can hold the Union to less than 25 points, they win. Victory conditions are slightly different for the Solitaire game.

First published in Command magazine No. 22 (May-June 1993).

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 hour
Hex: 250 yards
Unit: Brigade & Battery

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
Two countersheets (304 5/8" counters)
One 36 page rule booklet
6039.name: Antietam: Burnished Rows of Steel

boardgamehonor: 1991 Charles S. Roberts Best Post World War II Board Game Nominee
6040.description:
Ths game is a one- or two-player operational simulation of the Gulf War. It focuses almost exclusively on the Coalition ground war that liberated Kuwait and shattered the occupying Iraqi army.

The game includes a 22" x 34" hex map of the significant terrain in the Kuwaiti Theatre of Operations, 192 counters, and 20 pages of rules, charts, and tables.

Rules are split into both a basic and an advanced game. There are separate rules for solitaire play.

The U.S./Coalition player must completely liberate Kuwait to have a chance to win. If Kuwait is liberated within 12 game turns, the player who has gained the most 'points' in inflicting losses on their opponent, wins. The Coalition player must be aggressive in order to completly clear Iraqi units from all Kuwaiti cities, towns, oilfields, and airfields, otherwise the Iraqi player will win.
6040.name: Desert Storm: The Mother of All Battles

6041.description:
This is a simulation of the fighting in and around the capital of Hungary in January 1945.

The game is played for 14 turns and ends either with a political victory (control of Budapest) or a victory on points (given for destruction of opposing units).

It includes 16 pages of rules, a 22" x 34" mapsheet, two player aid cards, and 165 counters.
6041.name: Budapest '45

boardgamehonor: 1990 Charles S. Roberts Best World War II Board Game Nominee
6042.description:
What if the Americans did not develop the atom bomb? Would they have invaded Japan?

The game includes a 20 page rulebook, a 22 x 34" mapsheet, and 200 counters.

The U.S./Allied force is primarily trying to capture Japanese cities, thus denying that side the population and industrial base necessary to carry on the war. The Japanese are trying to inflict maximum casualties on the Allied force to demoralize them.

Four different scenarios are provided, each with their own set of victory conditions. A Victory Point Index is provided for each player to keep track of their points (range 1-100)... various rules take effect when the index is at various levels for each player. There are extensive rules for gaining and losing points (over one page of rules).
6042.name: Samurai Sunset

6044.description:
This is the hypothetical invasion on the Roman Empires of both the east and west, on the part of the hordes of the Huns.

Two elements essential to the game are the policy of alliances with other barbaric peoples (along with the activities of Pope Leo) and the calculation of cultivatable land devastated by the hordes of “Flagellum Dei”
Degree of difficulty: 2/6

Contents:

Pieces representing the barbarian hordes and the roman legions of the eastern and western empires.
6 heavy cards to be used to establish the outcome of combat.
6 heavy cards to be used to resolve diplomatic conflicts.
Combat and diplomacy tables.
Calendar with entries and deaths of various leaders and emperors subdivided into seasons.
Board in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
Plastic storage tray and one die.
6044.name: Attila

boardgamehonor: 1992 Charles S. Roberts Best Pre-World War II Board Game Nominee
6045.description:
This game is a two-player simulation of the Third Servile War, a slave revolt that shook the Roman Republic from 73-71 B.C.

Included in the game are 14 pages of rules, 189 5/8" counters, and a 22" x 34" mapsheet with the areas of Italy and the Mediterranean where the War of the Gladiators took place.

Barring the occupation of Rome (for the Rebel player) or the capture of Spartacus (for the Roman player), which would give an automatic victory, the game is played for points. At the end of 17 Turns, the player with the most points wins.
6045.name: I Am Spartacus!

6046.description:
This game is a simulation of the battle which took place between Lee's Army of Northern Virginia and Meade's Army of the Potomac at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania during the first four days of July 1863.
Included in the game are a 22 x 34" mapsheet, 200 counters, and 18 pages of rules.

To win the game, the Confederate player must inflict heavy casualties on the Union army and/or move his own train off the map to the southwest. The Union player must resist the Confederates drive while inflicting heavy losses on the Confederates.
6046.name: Gettysburg: Lee's Greatest Gamble

boardgamehonor: 1992 Charles S. Roberts Best Pre-World War II Board Game Nominee
6047.description:
Port Arthur is a simulation of the ground campaign of the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-05.
Included in the game are 10 pages of rules, a 22" x 34" mapsheet, and 101 counters.

Victory points are awarded for causing enemy casualties, and for control of Liaoyang, Mukden, and Port Arthur (which is worth 2 points). At the beginning of the game the Russian player will be receiving 4 points per turn, so it is imperative for the Japanese player to be aggressive. At the end of 10 complete turns, the player with the higher total, wins.
6047.name: Port Arthur: The Russo-Japanese War

6049.description:
Czechoslovakia '38, This game is a two-player wargame that simulates what might have been the first campaign of World War II in Europe if the Prague government rejected the Munich Diktat.

The game was first published as a supplement to Command magazine Issue #24.

To win, the German player must attempt to crush Czechoslovakia by conquering crucial territory before France and England decide to join the war. The Czech player wins by holding out until those two Allies intervene.

Game Scale:
Turn: 2 days
Hex: 7.5 miles / 12 km
Unit: Regiments to Divisions

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
One countersheet (176 5/8" counters - 142 for Czechoslovakia '38, the rest are errata counters for other games)
One 28 page Rulebook
6049.name: Czechoslovakia '38

boardgamehonor: 2009 Juego del Año Tico Nominee
6050.description:
From the Publisher:

Behind the stunning artistry of Duel of Ages lies an epic, deeply intriguing strategy game that will capture your attention for years to come. Build the uniquely modular game map (using the PAKIT board game system) to your own advantage, thwarting the enemy's attempt to do the same.

Accept a random roster of heroic characters, each with radically different abilities. Discover a way to turn this diverse group into an effective team. To survive, your team must acquire strange and deadly equipment by confronting the illusionary guardians of the labyrinths. But through every minute of play, the enemy will be uncomfortably close, hounding your team as you hound theirs...

Expanded by

Duel of Ages Set 2: Intensity
Duel of Ages Set 3: Vast Horizons
Duel of Ages Set 4: Royal Tournament
Duel of Ages Set 5: Mercenary Camp
Duel of Ages Set 6: Field of Honor
Duel of Ages Set 7: Ruins of Cany XII
Duel of Ages: Masters Addendum
Duel of Ages: Prestige Pack
Duel of Ages: Scrye Add-On Pack
6050.name: Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 11: How many sessions before judgment?

6051.description:
Up to 5 expeditions have gotten lost in the thick, impenetrable jungle.

Who will be the first person to leave this jungle unscathed? The successful person must find and make use of e- and m -business cards hidden in the mysterious pyramids of the jungle. Who will be the smartest player and reach the pyramids as quickly as possible? Who will be lucky enough to avoid meeting their fate and not succumb to swamps, floods, unfamiliar animals, disease and strange signs? Who will use items such as cell phone, laptop, GPS system, analysis equipment, webcam and PDA on their own, or with their fellow players, in the smartest way as to establish connections, fetch help, grasp the situation, fend off hunger, find paths, get the natives on their side and interpret strange signs correctly?
And, at the end of this exciting contest in the jungle, who will be have the good fortune and best overview to be able to tell apart the mysterious pyramids? The first person to leave the jungle with two e/m-jokers has earned our congratulations.
6051.name: Anaconda

6052.description:
Washington’s and Cornwallis’ problems for the decisive siege in the American War of Independence, reproduced on a 70x100 centimeter map, with the employment of all the American, French, Prussian and English units.

Degree of difficulty: 2/6

Contents:

79 cut out pieces, representing American, French, English and Prussian units which took part in the battle.
Explosion markers to show which units have been shot or damaged.
Combat disk, to check the results of battles and of artillery fire, with calendar.
York Town map and surroundings in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples and table of battle field forces.
Plastic storage tray and one die.
6052.name: York Town

6053.description:
Three games at different levels of difficulty reconstructing the most famous battle between the U.S. Army and the Indians. The three-dimensional board shows the Valley of Little Big Horn, from the high plains, just as Colonel Custer saw it before his last stand.

Degree of difficulty: 3/6

Contents:

Pieces in matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides.
Large cardboard table to be used to establish the outcome of combat and rifle fire.
Board in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
Relief sections in rigid, thick cardboard to be used to create the three-dimensionality of the terrain.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
Plastic storage tray and dice.
6053.name: Little Big Horn

6054.description:
This is the story of the great strategy used by the Germans to assure the success of their first landings in the 2nd World War. Six small tactical maps and one strategic map enable the player to follow the advance of the Germans, both on land and in the air and naval battles over the waters of the North Sea.

Degree of difficulty: 4/6

Contents:

Calendar in cardboard used to calculate the entry of the various units into the game.
Naval and land combat tables in cardboard printed in two colors.
Pieces in matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides representing German, Norwegian and Allied units.
6 tactical maps in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, printed in 5 colors.
Strategic map in rigid, thick cardboard used to carry out air and naval moves.
4 small grids to calculate moves off the map.
Tablet for the formation of convoys and the positioning of submarines
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
Plastic storage tray and dice
6054.name: Norge

6055.name: Chase Across the Planes
6055.description:
Chase Across the Planes is a boardgame for two to four players set in the worlds of the Intruder. The game was published in Intruder magazine #1.

Player assume the roles of supernatural characters who are testing their powers for the first time... each character has a special ability that allows them to 'bend' the rules in a slightly different way.

Players move around a small stylized mapboard that represents the different planes of existance, attempting to visit each one and 'leave their mark'. Along the way, they may battle other characters and/or destroy other player's markers.

As soon as a player has markers in all of the planes required (depending on the number of players, this can be 4 to 6), he wins.

6056.name: The Intruder Escapes
6056.description:
A quick two-player game that was published in Intruder magazine #2.

One player takes the role of Eric, the Intruder, and the other player plays the monstrous Golden Hoarde. The object for the Intruder player is to cross the map and enter the throne room, thus avoiding the Master of Chaos and winning the game. For the Golden Hoarde player to win, he must attack at any opportunity, to force Eric to lose his six starting 'life points', rendering him unconscious and subject to capture.

6057.name: Real-ity Estate
6057.description:
Two to six players deal in alternate dimensional 'real estate' in this game that was published in Intruder magazine #3.

Players move around the board trying to gain access to property in other dimensions. Players may recruit armies, fight for possession of dimensional 'real estate', plunder other players, and may have to overcome pitfalls along the way.

The first player to control points in all nine dimensions is the winner.

6058.description:
A two player boardgame set in the world of comic hero Agent 13. The game was published in 13: Assassin magazine #5.

Maggie Darr and her henchmen are trying to track down and kill Agent 13. At the same time, Agent 13 wants to capture Maggie Darr because she holds the secret to his past.

One player takes the role of Agent 13, the other, Maggie Darr. Agent 13 must either capture Maggie or find six clues to his past and return to his Headquarters to win. The only way that the 'Maggie' player can win is to eliminate Agent 13. There is no time limit to the game.
6058.name: The Quest for Maggie Darr

6059.name: Maison Ikkoku: Love's Roulette (Koi no Roulette)
6059.description:
Complexity level 1 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Love Attack to Kyoko in Maison Ikkoku

Tsukada takes a break from their usual 2 player science fiction wargames to make this boardgame based off the love/comedy manga (and anime) by Rumiko Takahashi. Unlike many of Tsukada's games, this actually is 2-6 players (not their usual "split up into 2 teams" multiplayer suggestion).

You have 3 markers to keep track of your attack points (as in getting the nerve to talk to her, not physically attack), your love points, and her emotion towards you. The game itself is of the roll-and-move variety, with 74 different event cards, each with scenes from the manga on them, that, along with the board spaces themselves, affect your markers.

6060.description:
Published in two parts in Intruder magazine #4 and #5, Interdimensional Chess is Chess with a twist.

Each game has a different theme (issue #4 is based in the world of Buck Rogers, issue #5 is based in the comic world of 'R.I.P.). Each chess piece has an additional power depending on the rules set used (e.g.-the King can move two spaces instead of one; the Succubus moves like a Bishop, but can 'fly' over friendly pieces).

Games are played like regular Chess - the object is to immobilize or 'checkmate' the opponent's king.
6060.name: Interdimensional Chess

6061.name: Second that Emotion
6061.description:
A simple card game for 2 to 6 players based on the world of Agent 13. The game was published in 13: Assassin magazine #4.

The game is basically a rummy-like game where some of the cards have special powers. Cards are melded to the table either in front of the person who played it or in front of an opponent. Each card has a specific number of points... either positive or negative (range -4 to +4).

The first player to have cards totaling 12 points is the winner.

6062.name: Attack of the Plant People
6062.description:
A two to four player abstract tactical game published in Warhawks magazine #6.

Players take the roles of up to four terrible 'Plant People', each with a different special power. Players alternate placing their vines on the board. When a square is surrounded on three sides it forms a pod (worth 3 points in combat). Players have either 8 or 12 pods depending on their special power.

When opponent's vines touch, there is combat... loser must remove all of the vines being attacked.

The object of the game is to completely choke out all other player's vines and pods, forcing them off the board.

6063.name: Escape from the Brotherhood
6063.description:
A solitaire game, based on the Agent 13 comic, published in 13: Assassin magazine #2.

All you have to do is get from Start' to the Agent 13 Cell by avoiding loss of life points and trying to evade as many random encounters as possible. There are more encounter tokens than game spaces, so every game is different.

6064.name: Race for the Crystal
6064.description:
A two-player boardgame based on the Agent 13 comic published in 13:Assassin magazine #3.

One player takes the role of Agent 13, the other is Agent 13's nemesis, China White, and her minions. Players alternate moving (resolving any random encounters) and then resolve any combat.

The first player to capture the power crystal and escape, or eliminate all of his opponent's characters, is the winner.

6065.name: Aura Battler Dunbine: Wing Caliver
6065.description:
Complexity rating 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Comes in a full-size box. Includes 3 new maps, counters, with additional and expanded rules.

Expands:

Aura Battler Dunbine

6066.name: Aura Battler Dunbine: Byston Well
6066.description:
Complexity rating 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Not an expansion to any other Aura Battler game, this game is completely stand-alone.

2 player ground based tactical wargame. 3-fold out mounted maps combine to make one big map.

6068.description:
From the slums, where purse-snatchers and courtesans work their respective trades, to the inner salons of the Louvre, where confessors, royal astrologers, musketeers, and court favorites mingle and scheme in hushed conversations, the position of King's Jeweler has suddenly become a lot more dangerous!

Set in Paris, on the eve of the French Revolution, Queen's Necklace is a game of gem-selling, influence, and intrigue at the court. Two to four players compete in the role of royal jeweler to sell rare jewels to the Queen and her court.

Jeweler's loupe in hand, you must decide how best to spend your hard-earned ducats: acquiring beautiful gems (diamonds, emeralds, and rubies); or buying the favors of the various court followers. After three years of craftsmanship, the jeweler who sells the most precious gems and builds the largest fortune will receive the coveted title of King's Jeweler and a place at the court!
6068.name: Queen's Necklace
boardgamepodcastepisode: Dukes of Dice - Ep. 62 - Rise of the Dress Lords
Episode 62- The Golden Ages and Angry Gaming

6069.name: Witches and Wizards
6069.description:
From the box:

The Evil Lords of the Dark Castle have stolen the gold from the Village of Hope. The townspeople need Witches and Wizards to return their chest of gold using your magical power. Will you win the race for the gold and be the first to safely return from the Enchanted Forest to the Village of Hope?

Contents:

Gameboard
Illustrated Story Book and Game Rules
8 Witches and Wizards Game Pieces
Spell-Caster Cards
Spell-Buster Cards
Gold Chest
1 Die

6070.name: The Battle For Smithville II: An R.I.P. Cardgame
6070.description:
The Battle for Smithville II is a two player card game. It was published in R.I.P. magazine #6.

Included in the game are rules and sheets of cut-apart cards.

Part rummy, part concentration, players play, then flip cards to match adversaries. If the adversaries battle, the player gains points. The one with the most points after all of the cards have been played, wins.

6071.description:
The Kit of Expansible in the Z Gundam Games

Yes, that's the official wording on the box.

Expansion set for either of the main Mobile Suit Z Gundam games (Titan being one of them). Includes a sheet of counters, and 36 data cards for easy reference for lots of different mechs (and a rulebook as well of course).

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

Expands:

Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Green Noa 1
Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Titans
6071.name: Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Gate of Zedan

6072.description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Mobilesuits Combat in Gundam

One of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam anime series from the early 1980s. This one has 7 different ground-based scenarios to fight. Includes many counters, a pad of record sheets, and 4 double-sided maps.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.
6072.name: Mobile Suit Gundam: Close Fight

6073.description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fleet Battle in the Gundam

Expansion set for Mobile Suit Gundam: New Type has additional units and rules aimed at making the game more dynamic. There were two versions of White Base released, with a different cover (other changes are uncertain).

Includes counters and 3 single sided mounted maps. 10 more scenarios are described in the rulebook.

Expands:

Mobile Suit Gundam: New Type
6073.name: Mobile Suit Gundam: White Base

6074.name: Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Green Noa 1
6074.description:
Complexity level 1 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fortress Combat in Z Gundam

Based off the Mobile Suit Z Gundam (Zeta Gundam) anime. This one has 4 different space-based scenarios to fight covering episodes 2 through 11 of the anime, overlapping the episodes that the "Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Titans" game covers.

Includes many counters and 3 single sided mounted maps.
Not as complex as some of the others in the series, the rulebook is just a few pages long.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Z Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

Expanded by:

Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Gate of Zedan

6075.description:
Complexity level 5 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fortress Combat in Z Gundam

1st wargame based off the Mobile Suit Gundam Z (Zeta Gundam) anime. This one has 4 different space-based scenarios to fight based off the first 11 episodes of the anime. Includes many counters and 6 single sided maps.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Z Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

Expanded by:

Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Gate of Zedan
6075.name: Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Titans

6076.description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

"The Game of Space Combat in Gundam"

3rd of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam from the early 1980s. This one has 12 different space-based scenarios to fight. Includes many counters and 4 single sided mounted maps.

Expanded by:

Mobile Suit Gundam: White Base
6076.name: Mobile Suit Gundam: New Type

6077.name: Mobile Suit Gundam: Fortress
6077.description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fortress Combat in Gundam

2nd of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam anime series from the early 1980s. This one has 7 different space-based scenarios to fight. Includes many counters and 4 single sided mounted maps.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

6078.description:
First of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam.　This game is covering the tactical level land battles in the story. Each unit represent a Mobile Suit, vehicle or Flak gun, but not include aircraft. The strength of mobile suit units is variable by attached weapons and pilots.

The basic game engine is reimplements from Squad Leader. In each player's turn, turn player manage movement and combat for own units, and opponent player manage defensive fire.

9 scenarios represent various situations based on story. Victory condition vary by scenarios, but mostly condition is destruction of all opponent units.

First edition rule (used green ink) was bit unclear, and too complex for newcomer. Therefor the rule has been updated twice. In first time update, newly rulebook was printed (used blue ink), its insert to reprint box, and also exchanged for former edition users. In second time update, was published on the Tsukuda Hobby's "Operation" magazine volume 1.

This game reprinted in 30th anniversary from Mega House.
6078.name: Mobile Suit Gundam: Jabro

6079.description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a hex-based wargame based on the 2nd Star Trek movie of the same name.

It claims 2-4 players, but like many of Tsukada's games, you have to split into 2 'teams' and share counters for more than 2 players; it's really just a 2 player game.

Includes 8 different scenarios to fight.
6079.name: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan

6080.name: Star Wars: Endor
6080.description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a Star Wars themed hex-based wargame based not on the entire Return of the Jedi movie, but just on Endor. This game has no relation to West End Games Star Wars: Battle for Endor game (other than being based off the same movie).

6081.name: Star Wars: Hoth
6081.description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a Star Wars themed hex-based wargame based not on the entire Empire Strikes Back movie, but just on the attack on Hoth. This game has no relation to West End Games' Assault on Hoth (other than being based off the same movie).

6082.name: Star Wars: Death Star
6082.description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a Star Wars themed hex-based wargame is based on the rebels attacking the Death Star.

While the box says 2-8 players, like many of Tsukada's games, over two players means "get on one of the two teams and share the counters"; it's really a 2 player game.

Tsukada could've paid more attention to their box.. Two things of note on the box:

1) On the front, it has the "Empire Strikes Back" logo on it, even though the game is based off the Death Star attack from the first movie. Most likely it's just because it came out after Empire Strikes Back, but..

2) On the back of the box, in says in English "May the forth be with you!"

6083.name: Jacob's Ladder
6083.description: The goal of this game is to construct a Frankenstein's Monster, or, in the games terms, a Surgically Composite Monster. Players do this by traipsing about the land mustering an army, battling neutral armies, and eventually collecting enough pieces to bring their monster to life. The battle is done in a mini-map fashion, titan style. Plenty of spells and items are sprinkled throughout.

6084.name: Place Your Bets!
6084.description:
Based on the 1974-75 game show Dealer's Choice, with a stake of $100 each player participates in five games of chance. Each game has been assigned rounds in which it may be played. The player designated as the dealer for each round chooses the game from a group of 12, all used on the show. The rules for each game are written on its board.

The final round is played with the Bonus Dice. The Bonus Dice have money amounts from $50 to $200 written on eleven of the twelve faces; the twelfth face contains a spade. Each player makes a secret guess how much money the Bonus Dice will accumulate before the spade is rolled. Those who come closest without going over get their holdings doubled. The player with the most money wins.

6085.description:
East & West is a hypothetical Russian attack on Europe and the consequences of the war on the three hottest fronts in the world.

Degree of difficulty: 6/6

Contents:

Card for electronic codes and sinking of reserves.
Cardboard table for launching of missiles, bombardments and battles.
570 pieces in plasticized, matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides.
3 maps in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 2 pieces and printed in 5 colours, they represent the three “warm” borders: Europe, the Middle East and the Russian-Chinese border.
Table for reserves and their transport.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
Plastic storage tray and dice.
6085.name: East & West

6086.description:
Landings and battles are displayed on two general maps while they are taking place on the island. Surprise techniques by the Japanese and the succession of land, air and naval battles in addition to historical faithfulness, make Okinawa a precise and amusing game.

Degree of difficulty: 3/6

Contents:

20 little maps to calculate the hidden position of Japanese forces and American movement.
2 tables to resolve combat and to calculate the artillery fire in matte finish plasticized cardboard.
166 counters in plasticized, matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides representing *American and Japanese units which took part to the battle.
Playing board in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
Plastic storage tray and dice.
6086.name: Okinawa

6087.description:
Landing in Sicily is, for the Allies, the first step in an Axis country and a possibility to change the historical course of the war.

Degree of difficulty: 5/6

Contents:

Cardboard tables to determine battle results, artillery fire and air bombardments.
Calendar with a list of towns and the exact date in which they were conquered.
250 pieces in plastic, matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides.
Board in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
Plastic storage tray and dice.
6087.name: Sicilia '43

6088.description:
The last great offensive of the German-Italian forces in Tunisia to halt the advance of the English and American forces which landed in Marocco in ’42. The board is a three dimensional map consisting of a reproduction of the area on three levels.

Degree of difficulty: 5/6

Contents:

7 cardboard tables to be used to establish the outcome of combat and artillery fire.
Calendar indicating the entries onto the battlefield, the rounds divided into days and nights, air raids and all other indications necessary to the game.
Pieces in matte finish cardboard, cut and coloured on both sides.
Board in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
Relief sections in rigid, thick cardboard to be used to create the three-dimensionality of the terrain.
Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
Plastic storage tray and dice.
6088.name: Rommel

6089.name: The 6 Pack of Paper & Pencil Games
6089.description:
This is a collection of special pads to play six paper-and-pencil games. Four of the games were apparently designed solely by Sid Sackson (they appeared under his name in early issues of Games magazine):

Oil Strike - 2-4 players. A dice-based placement game.
The Great Races - 2-4 players. This is reminiscent of Can't Stop and may be a precursor to that game.
Spy - 2 players. A deduction game.
Financier - 2-4 players. A stock market game.

The other two games may have been designed by Phil Orbanes Sr. or by Orbanes and Sackson together (the game credits both of them as designers):

Pay Off - 2-4 players. Another dice-based placement game.
Words Times Three - 1-4 players. An adaptation of a traditional game where players select letters in turn to be entered in a grid (each player using their own grid), but with hexagons instead of squares, allowing words to be formed in three directions.

6090.description:
12 cards (with positive, negative, and special powers) are revealed one after the other. Each time a card is revealed, the players try to acquire it by secretly choosing a number of flies(each player starts with 5 black plastic flies), and guessing the total number of flies chosen by all of the players. The used flies become the reserve in the middle of the table.

The player who guessed the correct number(or closest guess) gets the card and either keeps it, if it's a positive card, or gives it to another player, if it's a negative card.

There are 3 special power cards, Mireille, the (blue) Trained fly, who can be called back from the total, Insecticide which can eliminate the flies from opponents hands, and Fly Babies which allows players to take flies from the reserve.

If a player guesses the exact number of flies chosen by the group in a round, they get to take one fly from the reserve.

After all 12 cards have been acquired/distributed, the point values on the cards are totaled and added to the remaining flies a player possesses. The player with the most points at the end of the game will be the winner.
6090.name: Pack of Flies

6091.name: Dragon Buster
6091.description:
The 3rd in Namco's series of boardgames based off their videogames. This one is based off the old side view action/ROPG Dragon Buster.

The boardgame plays closest to Talisman, although it's not that close of a connection. You roll the dice to move around the board and complete quests. The game includes a variety of event cards, charts for randomizing events and encounters,counters for monsters and items and such. The point of this game to kill the dragon and rescue the princess (yes, a horribly cliched plot, but it was based off a very early videogame).

There is a considerable amount of Japanese not only in the rules, but on all the event cards and charts.

6092.name: Deadlands: Lost Colony – Showdown
boardgamefamily: From RPG books to board games
6092.description:
A collectible card game based on the Deadlands Lost Colony Roleplaying system.

Sold in starter sets of 65 cards and booster packs of 30 cards each.

6093.name: King of the Anthill
6093.description:
King of the Anthill was published in Intruder magazine #6. Can Eric, the Intruder, rescue the other humans before the they are trapped forever in this alternate dimension?

One player controls the interdimensional creatures trying to capture the humans and drag them deep into the 'Anthill'. The other player takes the role of the humans and attempts to escape from the top of the hill, battling native creatures along the way.

To win, the Human player must get all three humans to the top of the hill. The Native player wins if he can prevent this from happening.

6094.name: Orguss: Orguroid
6094.description:
Complexity level 2 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Battles in the Orguss

Based off the mecha anime "Orguss", this game takes place on the ground, over mountainous terrian. Includes counters and 3 single sided mounted maps.

6095.name: Orguss: Factory
6095.description:
Complexity level 4 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

The Diplomatic Game in Orguss

A break from Tsukada's usual 2 player science fiction hex-wargame fare. It's still science fiction, but this time it's a true 2-5 player game, more in the style of the old Avalon Hill's Diplomacy and Civilization games.

6096.name: Raid on the Bunker
6096.description:
This solitaire game was published in Warhawks magazine #1.

The Zetans have placed a bomb on the Time Platform... your squad of mercenaries must avoid or eliminate 14 Zetan guards in the research facility, without causing any casualties to the scientists, and get to the 'Time Platform' in seven game turns to win... easier said than done.

6097.description:
Alternate but not official title: "Heavy Metal L-Gaim Mark II"

Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this takes L-Gaim to space, with 6 single-sided space maps and 300 new counters. This is a seperate and complete game from the original, ownership of the original is not required. However, both games use the same expansion kit.

Expanded by:

Heavy Metal L-Gaim Expansion kit
6097.name: L-Gaim Mark II

6098.description:
Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this is a ground-based 2 player hex&counter wargame.

Includes 4 single-sided mounted maps and counters. There are rules for 3 different scenarios to fight.

Expanded by:

Heavy Metal L-Gaim Expansion kit
6098.name: Heavy Metal L-Gaim

6099.name: Raid on Bananama: The Bad Boys Game
6099.description:
A two-player game based on the Bad Boys comic series published in Warhawks magazine #2.

After the invasion of Bananama, the forces of the U.S. have taken El Presidente into custody... or have they? You play either the forces of the 'Bad Boys: American Special Forces', or 'The Cartel', the elite drug runners of the Third World. Each side wants El Presidente... the U.S., because he's been helping run drugs; the Cartel, to kill him before he talks.

Finding El Presidente will be difficult because of his duplicates, but if either player can get the real one to his HQ, he wins.

6100.description:
An expansion that can be used with either "Heavy Metal L-Gaim" (Tsukuda, not Bandai's one) or "L-Gaim Mark II". A sheet of counters and a rulebook with additional rules.
Very tough to get in even Japan, was originally sold via mail order in an envelope (similar to some Avalon Hill expansions).

Expands

L-Gaim Mark II
Heavy Metal L-Gaim
6100.name: Heavy Metal L-Gaim Expansion kit

6101.description:
Complexity rating 4 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based on the mecha science-fiction anime Aura Battler Dunbine. A 2-player hex-based ground mecha combat wargame.

Includes counters and 3 single-sided mounted maps. Rules included for a regular scenario and for a campaign game.
6101.name: Aura Battler Dunbine

6102.name: L-Gaim Mark II: Sveet
6102.description:
Complexity level 2 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this is a space-based 2 player hex & counter wargame.

Extremely tough to find in Japan, this is not an expansion to any of the other L-Gaim games, but an alternate, easier to learn (but of course still in Japanese) wargame.

6103.name: Craters of Tharsis
6103.description:
Craters of Tharsis is a two-player boardgame published in Buck Rogers magazine #3. It is based, in part, on the novel Hammer of Mars (also published by TSR). One player takes the role of the NEO freedom fighters, the other plays the omnipresent RAM.

The game includes a mapsheet of the area (where the battles for Mars take place), 6 pages of rules (covering basic initiative, movement, and attack phases), and one sheet of cut-out counters.

Victory points are given to each player for destroying (or stealing, for the NEO player) enemy units. The game ends when all NEO troops are killed or all RAM Krait fighters have left the map. The player with the most points wins.

6104.name: Battle for the Sprawls
6104.description:
Battle for the Sprawls is a two-player boardgame that was published in Buck Rogers #2. The game is loosely based on the novel Rebellion: 2456 by M.S. Murdoch.

Each player plays one side of the conflict, either NEO (New Earth Organization) or RAM (Russo-American Mercantile), the current masters of Mars.

The game includes a map (which represent the sprawls of Old Chicagorg), 3 pages of rules (covering basic initiative, movement and combat procedures), and one sheet of cut-out playing pieces.

The game is decided on Victory Points, which are given for eliminating opponent's units, or for destroying enemy transports. Effectively, to win as the NEO player, you must get more of your transports off the ground than have been destroyed.

Additional, optional rules are provided for ranged combat, transport defenses, and secret passages.

6105.name: The Gauntlet
6105.description:
The Gauntlet is a two-player boardgame that was published in Buck Rogers magazine #1.

One player is Anatoly Karpov, the renegade Russian general who has stolen the Masterlink, a space based weapon satellite. The other player is Col. Anthony 'Buck' Rogers, America's greatest pilot.

The game contains a map, 8 pages of rules, 106 cut-apart counters, and player ship displays.

The U.S. player wins if Masterlink is destroyed. The Soviet player wins if Buck Rogers is killed and Kharkov survives, no matter how badly Masterlink is otherwise damaged. Special tournament victory conditions are also provided based on varying levels of victory.

6106.name: Zombie Rampage
6106.description:
Zombie Rampage, the Battle for Smithville (Part III), is a two player tactical game that was published in R.I.P. magazine #3. One player takes control of the Zombies and one player takes control of the unsuspecting humans.

THe game includes a stylised map of Smithville, 3 pages of rules, and one sheet of cutout counters.

To win, the Zombie player must kill all the Humans so that the Zombies can continue to try to destroy America in the 'Zombie Nation' game (q.v.). THe Human player must kill all the Zombies so that the events in 'Zombie Nation' do not occur.

6107.name: Attack in the Asteroids
6107.description:
Attack in the Asteroids, published in Buck Rogers magazine #5, is a simplified version of the tactical ship-to-ship combat game from the XXVc Roleplaying game. The game covers a battle between Black Barney, in the ship 'Free Enterprise' and three RAM battle cruisers.

The game contains a hex mapsheet, 3 pages of basic rules, ship charts, and a sheet of cut-out counters.

To win, either the Black Barney player or the RAM player must completely destroy the other player's ship(s).

6108.name: Zombie Nation
6108.description:
Zombie Nation, the Battle for More than Smithville (Part IV), is a game for two players that continues the battle started in Zombie Rampage (q.v.). This game was published in R.I.P. magazine #4.

The game contains a map of the U.S., 3 pages of rules and one sheet of cutout counters.

The Zombie player has sent out mystical Graveyard Icons across the U.S. and the Army has been called in to put a stop to any further uprisings. To win, the Zombie player must destroy all of the Army forces. The Army player must destroy all of the Zombies and their icons.

6109.name: Mafia
6109.description:
2/4 "Families" players try to get the control of Sicily: they throw the die and move around a 8-shaped pattern, getting control of the cases. Some of them have also positive or negative effects.

Families are composed of a Boss and several young members. They can also fight each other and steal posses of cases of other families. Another player is the Italian State, using a Prefetto, three Carabinieri (military police) units and a secret services man. He must arrest all the Mafia men he can.

Mafia is a simple game with an unusual setting, that aroused some discussion in Italian newspapers when it came out.

6110.description:
The goal of the game is to form red alignments of 4 points or more. The points can be pawns or points marked on the board.

The pawns are placed on a grid which moves within a framework.
6110.name: Abraxas

6111.description:
From the box:

The realistic battle game which recreates the historic confrontation between George Armstrong Custer’s 7th U.S. Cavalry regiment and the several thousand Sioux, Cheyenne and other Indian warriors led by Sitting Bull, Crazy Horse and various other chiefs. It is once again June, 1876, and you are at the Battle of the Little Big Horn.

Contents: 280 counters, 7 7-hex Indian camps, 2 maps, & time record sheet
6111.name: Little Big Horn: Custer's Last Stand

6112.name: Battle Dome
6112.description: Battle Dome is "the game of rapid-fire action and lightning-quick reflexes!" It is a pinball-style game in which colored plastic marbles fall from a motorized dispenser down onto a dome, and then fall into one of four chutes. Players 2-4 control a set of flippers at their chute and try to shoot the falling balls into their opponent's goals while keeping marbles out of theirs. Any marbles in your goal count against you, with the black "stealth" marble counting extra. There are spinners and bells on the dome that the marbles hit - these can be rearranged, or replaced by a fence to block off one or two chutes if there are fewer than 4 players.

boardgamehonor: 2003 Origins Awards Best Board Game Expansion Winner
6113.description:
Zombies!!! 3 Mall Walkers adds a whole new level of excitement to shopping. Enter the front door, find what you need, and try to escape alive! Above all, "Shop 'til you TRULY drop!"

This expansion could be played stand-alone with shotgun guys (or other player markers) and tokens for bullets and hearts.

Part of the Zombies!!! series.
6113.name: Zombies!!! 3:  Mall Walkers

6114.name: Goosebumps: Shrieks and Spiders Game
6114.description:
A simple variant of the game Spoons (as if Spoons weren't simple enough). Plastic spiders are put in the center of the table (one less than the number of players). Each player is given a scoreboard and four tokens to put in it. Each player is then dealt a stack of cards face-down in front of them.

Each turn the players simultaneously turn over the top card from their stack. If any of the turned-over cards shows a skeleton, the players yell "Goosebumps" and grab one of the spiders from the center of the table. The player who didn't get a skeleton must turn in one of their tokens. Play then continues. The game ends when one player has discarded their last token, at which time the player with the most tokens remaining is the winner.

6115.name: I Ching la voie du Ta Tchouan
6115.description:
The way of the Ta tchouan (named I CHING in France) gather two players in the same goal : drawing a path through the board with identical square pawns (named Quarks) in order to reach the opposite edge with their color own, black or white, yin or yang... Each quark is composed by an equal part of the way for the two players.

Based on the "Book of Changes" like the Go does, this connection game provided a wide panel of strategy with only two simple rules :
- INFLUENCE : you can't play around the last Quark played
- OPPOSITION : you can't break the paths, instead, you should build at least one of them by playing adjacent Quarks.

Initially build for a 6x6 pawn game, the cards provided in the Ta Tchouan box allow you to play on a 7x7, and it's not physically bound except by the time you need to play on an infinite x infinite board !!!

6117.description:
As sunset approaches in Littleton, Kentucky, Farmer Johnson’s chickens have had a hard day scratching, pecking and egg laying. But now it’s getting dark—time to return to the coop and get a good night’s sleep.

Unfortunately, a pack of foxes have found the coop and when the rats show up, they’ll snatch every chicken they can lay their fangs on, even if they have to make more than one trip to do it.

Will the loyal guard dogs save the chickens from the foxes, or will a rat sneak in and snatch the best chicken for itself? Only you will decide!

Nobody But Us Chickens is a fast-paced, Simultaneous Action Selection card game where players earn points by capturing chickens with their predators (foxes and rats) or protecting chickens with their guard dog. The game is easy to learn, but exciting and unpredictable.
6117.name: Nobody but Us Chickens

6118.name: Discovery
6118.description:
Discovery (also sold as Destination Tresor in French, and Discovery Island in Sweden) is an interesting deduction game of discovery. Each player begins in an unknown location on an island (the opponent picks where the other starts), and each has the same goal: find the hidden treasure. The treasure is hidden in one of 28 spots on the island, and there are 7 clues available in special checkpoints to help determine where it is. The island is made up of 5 different types of terrain, and for each type of terrain there is a set of corresponding hexes.

In play, one player calls a direction (Northeast, South, etc.) and the other player (who knows where you are) reveals a hex on the type of terrain you just stepped into. On the back of the hex there is a number, showing how many hours have been used. Each turn, a player gets 12 hours worth of movement. By moving this way, you can eventually figure out where you are and then start moving with more accuracy.

The game uses a clever device that reveals only one spot of a 6 x 6 matrix. A card, from a large set, is initially placed and this determines where the treasure will be for that game. When players get to a checkpoint, they can reveal that spot on the card to get a clue. The clues can tell you which of 4 types of treasure spots is "live", and also the six surrounding terrain types. The board is well designed so that with a few clues you can narrow down the options of spots.

A clever system in a tense and interesting game design.

Components:
2x Map boards
2x Plastic map sheets
1x Checkometer
28x Checkometer cards
18x Equipment cards
2x Whiteboard pencils
210x Terrain tiles divided as
- 20x Plain tiles
- 82x Jungle tiles
- 35x Mountain tiles
- 50x Swamp tiles
- 20x Outback tiles
- 4x Special tiles

6119.description:
Our galaxy has been invaded by an alien Space Station whose powerful laser beam is drawing vital energy pods away from your spaceships.

Your mission is to attack and destroy this violator of the Inter-Galactic Peace Accord. You must gather up your scattered energy pods before you risk an assault on the space station. Then, using your energy pods, you block its ports, causing the laser to overload and self-destruct.
6119.name: Laser Attack

6121.description:
Tablut is a traditional tafl game played on a 9x9 grid and is described at. The game was originally recorded by Linnaeus in Lappland in 1732, but is thought by a few scholars once to have been played throughout Sweden. [Given the lack of documentation of this game before Linnaeus' account, I find that opinion difficult to maintain, but it exists nonetheless.]

game description for Swords & Shields
One player controls the Shields and the other controls the Swords. The Swords player must try to capture the Chief Shield, while the Shields player must clear a safe path for the Chief Shield to escape off the board. Pieces can move any number of spaces in a straight line, and are captured when bracketed on two opposite sides by opponent pieces.
boardgameversion: Gamut of Games International Series Edition
6121.name: Tablut

6122.name: Star Wars: Escape the Death Star Action Figure Game
6122.description:
From the Box:

Board the Death Star... for a fight to the finish!

Recreate classic Star Wars movie battles in two games! In the first, for younger players, Luke Skywalker, Han Solo, Princess Leia and Chewbacca sneak through the Death Star capturing Imperials. Can you score the most captures?

Now advance to the next game - and take sides! Darth Vader, Boba Fett and stormtroppers move in the open, capturing Code Cards to win. But the Rebels move in secret. To win, they must use strategy to reach the Millenium Falcon, then dice-roll their way off the Death Star!

Add other action figures you already own...and fill the game board with life-like Star Wars characters!

Action figures bring intergalactic battles to life! For even more action, add your own figures!

The game originally came with two limited edition Star Wars: Power of the Force action figures that were unavailable anywhere else:


Death Star Darth Vader (with removable helmet and lightsaber)
Stormtrooper Disguise Luke Skywalker (with removable helmet and lightsaber).
